so and then are you getting all you can

going to take a look at a specific
deployment that we did for an IOT
company our rather a transportation
company that has quite a few IOT devices
they currently have 80,000 IOT devices
split across 30,000 different trucks in
Europe they were writing terabytes of

that data was providing them was audit
capability they could go back and tell
me tell themselves where a truck were
was three days ago or four days ago but
they couldn't tell you where it was
right now and if it was experiencing any
issues so we had some specific
challenges when we were migrating this
customer in they had very peaky
workloads so they were slow on the
weekends when they're not delivering a
whole lot and then on Monday morning all
that traffic spikes like crazy and
they're using what we actually call
legacy devices at this point it feels
weird to say legacy IOT devices but
that's what this company has they were
installed in the late 90s and they're
really reaching end-of-life but the
customer still needs to use them so we
specifically went with the i/o device
IOT platform for this deployment we were
really happy with the device gateway
message broker and how that would work
it would scale really immediately and
almost infinitely and it really allowed
us a lot of flexibility inside of the
environment so when we deployed this we
deployed this with five and a half
million IOT rules executed this produced
nearly 2.6 million or nearly 2.7 million
AWS IOT messages and we had a hundred
and fifteen thousand simultaneous
connections from trucks we were doing
auto scaling using some pretty large r44
Excel instances we'd go from two to nine
instances and we had three thousand
docker containers on top of each one so
what did this look like the IOT devices
inside the trucks would hit an elastic
load balancer into docker containers
running on that auto scaling group with
the r4 lot instances we then use the a
IOT engine to feed into a V PC for our
dynamo and RDS
lambda all using elastic search we then
deploy that across lambda back into an
SNS topic into the API gateway to then
feed that these IOT smart devices which
are the actual handheld devices that the
drivers are using and then we can take
all of the alerts coming out of that V
PC and deliver those into a slack
channel for for our customer so anytime
a truck hits a certain speed threshold
anytime a truck is somewhere where it
shouldn't be on its route we can
immediately deliver that that alarm back
to their control center and they can
really take that take that information
and make it immediately valuable however
what we've noticed with AWS
is that every once in a while you have a
problem you start losing s3 buckets
maybe your dynamo DB DB tables aren't
working anymore
maybe you've lost the ability to auto
scale and that's really where we start
delivering on our core competency at
SunGard which is our ability to deliver
these resilient managed services are
fully production are fully recoverable
production services so if we go back
into the recovery architecture when we
architected this we didn't just
architect it with production in mind we
architected it with potential failures
in mind as well so the first thing that
we do is we use our open source tool
called condensation which is available
today out on github it's been available
for about two years now and we use it in
all of our AWS deployments it allows us
to continually modify and redeploy
CloudFormation scripts without going in
and manually manipulating individual
lines
of code we pair that with s3 replication
and diamond DynamoDB table replication
into a source V PC in a different region
we take that EBS volume replication
which is part of our cloud recovery for
AWS product and then at time of tester
disaster so what if we start losing
those s3 buckets if we lose those ec2
instances we are instantly deploying
inside of a new region because all of
our data is already there we're
rehydrating that data we're presenting
it to ec2 instances and everything is
back up and running in a matter of
minutes so when we talk about s3
failures the one that we saw back in
February was I believe seven or eight
hours so you're down for the down for an
entire day but when we're utilizing our
recovery services on top of production
the total outage time is around 10 to 15
minutes which is a really just dynamic
deployment for the customer so all in
all what this delivered for our customer
was real-time analytics for their entire
fleet before they just had audit data
audit data is great if you need to know
where something was last week but what
this delivers now is that ability to
automatically see where everyone inside
of your fleet is at all times we can
also use this to push updates to devices
at turn-up like I said these devices
aren't on all the time they're off on
the weekends so what we can do now is
create a new image create that ghost
image and then as soon as that device
comes up inside of the cut inside of the
delivery truck it's like it sparks a
connection to the darker instances
inside of ec2 and we will automatically
take that update directly from the
device shadow to the device so that
means that we don't have to be there and
be around every time a truck turns up to
update the device it will do it
automatically when it turns on we're
also doing dynamic metrical learning for
the customer so like I mentioned before
we can do speed alerts for the customer
and we can pair that with GPS data from
open Maps so we can actually the same as
you would in your car it knows what if
you're in if you have a fairly new car
it knows what speed what the speed limit
is on any on any given street we're
doing that for the customer now too so
if they if the truck is breaking the
speed limit
and it doesn't matter what street it's
on we know that that's happening so the
customer was using audit data be using
all of this for audit data before and
they're continuing to use that for audit

with the customer now inside of AWS it's
not just about the data being there and

anymore it's about the data being there
and available and we know we have
specific log alerts going on so there's
no ability to modify those logs we're
doing all sorts of log management for

logs we can do that auto-scaling for

then then as I mentioned doing the

gives you that fully resilient solution
so when we go back and take a look at
lessons learned we I really do think
there is a case for DIY in the IT field
if you're going to do it know your costs
upfront know exactly what that
deployments going to look like you have
to know where you differentiate so if
you're just taking your existing
infrastructure and moving it to the

all your customers don't care if it's
the same infrastructure what you need to
do is take specific action and look
where the cloud can provide you with
specific business benefits when moving
you need to know how you'll support
after implementation because it's a lot
different than it is inside of your data
center today and you have to know if
cloud is going to solve your problems or
just move your problems if you're just
doing a lift and shift that's not

personally recommend is go out and find

for today an architect for tomorrow when

helping them utilize all of the
